narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Ability to track themes across large swaths of American history, read a lot of historical texts and analyze, write 20 pg paper (not research).

Tracing a Christian narrative about America being a city on a hill through its various major wars, looking at some religious roots of American exceptionalism and learning about the concept of a civil religion

I learned extensively about the history of America and religion. Basically, the history of America IS religion. Very much not what I had learned in high school. I really appreciated the depth the course went into as it served additionally as a kind of American history class. However, I feel that the greatest knowledge I came away with has been just how influential religion has been and continues to be. I also developed the ~skill~ of writing a 20 page paper, which I had not thought myself capable of.
Overview of major American wars, but from the perspective of religious motivations. Emphasis on historical trends.
A history of American self-conception and how it's tied up in a salvation narrative and war

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength- great discussion and mix of lecture and student contributions, interesting subject and readings, Professor Stout in incredibly nice, easy to talk to, accessible for office hours, and just a great professor!
Weakness- you won't get a ton of feedback on grades

Very interesting subject matter and discussions. Professor Stout was very knowledgable and posed thought-provoking questions. One of the main textbooks used is not the most engaging, but the primary sources are definitely engaging.
The strength of this course is Professor Stout. The only weakness of this course is not being able to interact with him in person.
It would be helpful to have the overview of whichever war we were studying the week before we focused on it, so that the readings would have more context.
The professor of course is an expert. My biggest gripe is that many of the students had little background in Christianity, so a lot of the class was eaten up by basic theology/Christian teaching.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual seminar was great, especially because Professor Stout purposefully made the class so small (8 people).
Professor Stout did a very good job of managing zoom -- I don't believe our section ever had any problems. I also really appreciated his use of a break at the hour mark.
I thought it worked quite well, despite the virtual environment.
N/A

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It is a fair amount of reading, but discussions are great! Papers are totally open ended. Stout is incredible.
Yes. You get to learn and think a lot about how two major aspects of America interact and influence each other. It's fun. The workload is reasonable.
Yes! This course was recommended to me by a dear friend and I will continue to sing its praises to everyone I know.
Yes, the course frames the historical events that most people have studied a number of times in a new and interesting way. The students it attracts also seem to be very smart and engaged.
Like I said earlier, you will get more out of the course if the other students are focused in religious history,
